captions.text:
Physicists used to think that the universe
had existed forever, unchangingly, because

that's what their observations of the night
sky suggested. Needless to say, this view

clashed with the "origin" or "creation" stories
of most major religions, which hold that the
universe had a beginning.

So it's not surprising that it was a Catholic
priest, Georges Lemaître, who was one of

the first major proponents of a new scientific
viewpoint - that the universe DID have a beginning.

Lemaître, of course, was also an excellent
mathematician and scientist and based this

conviction not (just) on his religious beliefs
but upon new experimental evidence from Edwin

Hubble that showed the universe was expanding.
This evidence, combined with the mathematics

of general relativity allowed Lemaître to
"rewind" cosmic history and calculate that

the farther back in time you go, the smaller
the universe had to be. The natural conclusion

is that everything we can currently see in
the universe was at one point in time more

or less at one point in space. Lemaître called
this idea the "primeval atom", but of course
today we know it as "the big bang theory".

Except "big bang" is a horrible name - it
would be much more accurate to call it "the

everywhere stretch". Because one of the most
common misconceptions about the big bang is

that it implies that the entire universe was
compressed into a single point from which

it then somehow expanded into the surrounding...
nothingness? It is true that the observable

universe, that is, the part of the whole universe
we can see from earth, WAS indeed shrunk down

to a very very small bit of space, but that
bit of space was NOT a single point, nor was

the rest of the Universe also in that same
bit of space.

The explanation for this is the magical power
of infinity. The whole universe is really

big - current data show it's at least 20 times
bigger than the observable universe, but that's

just a lower bound - it might be infinite.
And if you have an infinite amount of space,

you can scale space down, shrink everything
to minuscule proportions, and still have an

infinite amount of space. Kind of like how
you can zoom out as much as you want from

a number line, but it'll still be an infinite
number line.

Essentially, space doesn't need anywhere to
expand "into" because it can expand into itself

and still have plenty of room. In fact, this
is possible even if space turns out not to

be infinite in size, though the reasons are
complicated and have to do with the infinite
differentiability of the metric of spacetime...

But anyway, the event unfortunately known
as the big bang was basically a time, long

ago, when space was much more squeezed together,
and the observable universe, that is, everything

that we see from earth, was crammed into a
very very small piece of space. Because the

ENTIRE early universe was dense and hot everywhere,
spacetime was curved everywhere and this curvature

manifested itself as a rapid expansion of
space throughout the universe. And although

people call this "the big bang", it wasn't
just big, it was everywhere. And it wasn't

really an explosion - it was space stretching
out. It's really quite unfortunate that "the

Everywhere Stretch" isn't nearly as catchy
as "the Big Bang".

Which brings us to the "big bang singularity",
which is an even horribler name because every

single word is misleading. I mean, "singularity"
seems to imply something that happened at

a single point. Which isn't at all what it's
referring to - it SHOULD be called "the part

of the Everywhere Stretch where we don't know
what we're talking about." Basically, our

current physical models for the universe are
unable to properly explain and predict what

was happening at the very very beginning when
the universe was super SUPER scaled down.

But rather than call it the "time when we
don't have a clue what was happening, ANYWHERE",
for some reason we call it a "singularity".

This ignorance, however, does conveniently
answer the question What happened BEFORE the

big bang? Because it tells us the question
isn't well defined - back when space was so

incredibly compressed and everything was ridiculously
hot and dense, our mathematical models of

the universe break down SO MUCH that "time"
doesn't even make sense. It's kind of like

how at the north pole, the concept of "north"
breaks down - I mean, what's north of the

north pole? The only thing you can say is
that everywhere on earth is south of the north

pole, or similarly everywhen in the universe
is after... the beginning.

But once time began, whenever that was, space
expanded incredibly quickly all throughout

the universe - for a little while. Then expansion
slowed, the universe cooled, stuff happened,
and after a few billion years, here we are.

One thing we still DON'T know is why this
Everywhere Stretching happened - that is,

why did the universe start off in such a funny,
compressed state, and why did it follow the

seemingly arbitrary laws of physics that have
governed its expansion and development ever
since?

For Georges Lemaître, this might be where
God finally comes into the picture to explain

the things science can't. Except that experimental
evidence doesn't actually rule out the possibility

that there may indeed be a time "before" the
beginning, a previous age of the universe

that ended when space collapsed in on itself,
getting quite compressed and dense and hot,

but not enough to mangle up our ideas of what
time is. It would have then bounced back out,

stretching in a fashion similar to what we
call the big bang, but without the "we don't

know what we're talking about" singularity
part. So, physics may actually be nudging

us back to the view that the Universe is eternal
and didn't begin after all. In which case

Professor Lemaître might have to rethink
his interpretation of the words "in the beginning."

title: Science, Religion, and the Big Bang

comments.text:
It strikes me that so many people might consider being religious as 
"following the herd". What I see is that religion is the new taboo, and 
some people are becoming atheists as if it were some sort of trend, and 
this includes people with little to no actual scientific knowledge. We 
should take a more open-minded approach on knowledge itself, spread it 
around, not shove it in a can and label it, or rub it in people's faces. 
The reason why I like these videos is that they're not pretentious, and 
they're highly informative. It's what we have discovered until now, and 
it's amazing what we can discover in the future. Let's focus on that; 
claiming that god exists or doesn't exist is too large of a premise, not to 
mention it's irrelevant.﻿

how it is commonly used in the lay public," said Jaime Tanner, a professor 
of biology at Marlboro College. "Most people use the word 'theory' to mean 
an idea or hunch that someone has, but in science the word 'theory' refers 
to the way that we interpret facts.

comments.author: falconarea

comments.text:
Many years ago (1999) I asked myself, "If mathematical equations can be 
combined, why can't I combine physics equations?" in a fit of excitement, I 
got my college physics books out and perused them for physical laws I could 
combine. Newton's Force of Gravitation (F=GMm/rr) looked strikingly similar 
to Coulomb's Electromotive Force (F=KQq/rr) I set them equal to each other.

I know what you are thinking, because I have heard it all before, "Gravity 
and charge operate on totally different scales." Although, gravity 
dominates on the cosmic scale and charge dominates in the atomic scale; 
isn't it reasonable to assume, there exists a scale somewhere between where 
they are somewhat comparable. Perhaps the scale where charge and gravity 
share similar quantities is the engineering level. For example a maglev, or 
an elevator, or static electricity making your hair stand out like a 
dandelion.

When I put Coulomb's Electromotive Force equal to Newton's Force of Gravity 
with algebra, a dichotomy happened. Fortunately, the distance squared 
between the two objects, rr, canceled in both equations. Unfortunately, so 
did the units of force. I thought, "a physical equation without any units 
isn't very useful." So then, I multiplied by Einstein's Energy Equation 
(E=Mcc). There was two really good things that happened when I did this. 
Good thing one, I got some units back; instead of force it was an energy 
equation now. Good thing two, the capital M, the big mass, also cancelled, 
leaving me with the equation...

E=LQq/m where L=ccK/G=1.2105e37(Kilogram*meters/Coulomb/Seconds)^2

As you can see by the units in L and the variables in this energy equation 
that the mass in the denominator will cancel just one Kilogram in the 
numerator and both Coulombs in the denominator will cancel with both 
charges in the numerator. This leaves Kilogram * meters^2 / seconds^2 being 
the same units for Joules, a measure of energy.

There are many implications made by my energy equation I call "The 
Algebraic Mesh of Three Physical Laws." One of them is for two non zero 
charges and at least one of the objects having zero mass, an infinite 
energy comes out of this equation. This is similar to the big bang. 
Basically asserting a new universe is born with every photon. The need for 
the universe behaving in a modally different way from what we observe is no 
longer needed. This lends to the idea that the universe has always been 
here, forever behaving as we see it now. The reason we do not see an 
infinite energy coming from a lightbulb is because almost all of it is 
exhibited outside our velocity bubble { the part of Einstein's energy 
equation that keeps everything in our visible universe within the speed of 
light [ (1-vv/cc)^0.5 ] }

My equation with the velocity bubble included becomes simply...

E=LQq/m(1-vv/cc)^0.5

My equation also has something to say about Dark Energy and Dark Matter. 
These mysterious forces all around us are the gravitational effects of 
objects outside the velocity bubble. In the same way a Black Hole's gravity 
pulls light into it, transcending light's speed, Dark Matter's gravity 
reaches into our visible universe to hold the matter of galaxies together. 
Dark Energy, the stuff that seems to be accelerating the universe apart, is 
again objects outside the velocity bubble tugging on matter here in our 
visible universe, only very far away. In summery, Dark Matter are objects 
close by and Dark Energy are objects extremely distant. We can only observe 
the effects of their gravity because they are moving faster then light.

If you break velocity in the velocity bubble into the discrete components 
and solve for time you get the true meaning of time.

t=d/c(1-[LQq/mE]^2)^0.5

...where t is time and d is a distance vector from v of the velocity bubble.

If there is a way to force LQq/mE to equal the value 1 time gets warped and 
you could find yourself in limbo, a place where time stands still. Inside 
the temporal asymptotes, on either side of zero, is a place where time 
could be moving in a very different way from how we normally experience it, 
or possibly backwards.

The assertion that the universe was in a categorically different state in 
the distant past "The Big Bang" is a fallacy. In light of this new equation 
it seems that the universe is infinitely old and has had no other state 
then the one observed.﻿

that an anthropomorphic god is the creative agent before the big bang, yet 
it's also unfair to use the term 'god', drifting away from religious 
concepts, to describe whatever proponent of the creation of the universe we 
don't understand, because the term has it's meaning and it's not that. No 
need to give the religious that kind of encouragement. Whatever we discover 
will be something different and ought to be known as something different.﻿

comments.author: S.A Rohan

comments.text:
Science is a method to determine things about the physical world.

Spirituality is a method to determine things BEYOND the physical world. 
(metaphysics)

Neither one can determine if one or the other exists or proves the other, 
because they're the wrong tool.

Science determines things about the physical world.

Metaphysics determines thing beyond physics.

Using science to try and disprove religion is like using a hammer to solder 
a wire, It's simply the wrong tool.﻿
comments.author: DerickTherving

comments.text: +DerickTherving give this man a medal
comments.author: Slim Shady

comments.text:
If religion gives a person meaning in life. Why then is it a bad thing? I 
speak of course only for those who are accepting and educate themselves on 
what it is they believe, as one's own happiness should not come at the 
expense of others. If one is accepting of other people's practices and 
truly loves them, and they still hold their own beliefs and enjoy life, 
then It shouldn't quite matter whether a person is religious or not. We 
can't prove or disprove religion, But we also can't say what the last digit 
of Pi is, or "e", Or any other transcendental or irrational number for that 
matter. Because we're human, and there are things in this universe we may 
never understand with our limited human minds. But we can make 
approximations.


If you ask me, that's why we have so many different religions. In all 
honesty I wouldn't take my Catholic faith as being One Hundred percent 
perfect in everything it teaches, Simply because we're all humans and our 
minds are undoubtedly limited. In the same way If you were to attempt to 
solve an algebraic equation containing Pi you answer would come out to an 
approximation. 

But the answer is still considered right isn't it?
Even if it's not one hundred percent accurate. We as humans can't fathom 
what the real answer is.

Just as if I were to tell you:

Pi =Approximately 3.141592653
or
Pi = Approximately 3.141593
or
Pi = Approximately 3.14

They're all correct. Just one is more accurate

I think the same way about religion.
They're all close approximations of something we can't fathom. All correct 
though, all with good values (Excluding some perverted extreme ones). And 
I, Just as everyone else, Believe the one I live my life by is the most 
accurate. Doesn't mean the rest are wrong. They may experience the same 
constant joy as I do and I'd be glad that they do. 
So why is it bad?

comments.text:
I will argue that it is not likely that there was a big bounce. If there 
was, then there could very well be no beginning. But that poses another 
problem. You cannot complete an infinite amount of past events. Suppose you 
started reading a car manual that had an infinite amount of pages. If you 
started reading it, you would never reach the end. Similarly, If there was 
infinity before the beginning of the universe, a "big bounce" would have 
never happened.﻿
